patch-scripts/EXAMPLE_KUBELET/centos/EXA.message:
We normally wouldnt include TIS here.  STX might make better sense.
Then again, we have tis sprinkled all over (like tis_patch_ver)  so it doesnt really matter to me.

patch-scripts/EXAMPLE_KUBELET/scripts/ku.message: could have just done "if is_storage" and exited early to save an indentation level, but then you'd lose the single exit point so could go either way

Done.
Simple de-indent of the remaining block of code.
how long does the auto-restart state last?  are we guaranteed to catch it?  Would we be better off just waiting for the pid to change and then telling pmon to start it up again?

Also note kubelet.conf pmon config:
more kubelet.conf 
;
; Copyright (c) 2019 Wind River Systems, Inc.
;
; SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
;
[process]
process  = kubelet
service  = kubelet
pidfile  = /var/run/kubelet.pid
style    = lsb            ; lsb
severity = critical       ; minor, major, critical
restarts = 3              ; restarts before error assertion
startuptime = 5           ; seconds to wait after process start
interval = 5              ; number of seconds to wait between restarts
debounce = 20             ; number of seconds to wait before degrade clear
subfunction = last-config ; run monitor only after last config is run

Entire script typical success < 2 seconds.
* The codeblock waiting for process stopped < 1 second, script tunable set to wait max 30 seconds elapsed.

* The codeblock waiting for new process started < 1 second, script tunable set to wait max of 15 seconds elapsed.

If there was a problem with new kubelet binary, it would timeout in the start loop and at approximately 17 seconds overall elapsed time, with $PATCH_STATUS_FAILED.

This script is already robust and we've tried this specific script verbatim before, i am inclined to leave pid wait logic as-is.

Note the kubelet systemd service has RestartSec=10 .

cat /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/kubeadm.conf
[Service]
. . .
Restart=always
StartLimitInterval=0
RestartSec=10

And,
cat /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/kube-stx-override.conf 
[Unit]
# Add a dependency to kubelet on config so it doesn't enter a bad state on subsequent boots
After=config.service

[Service]
# pmond monitors kubelet.service
Restart=no

> see the comment. The only reason why do rmdir is that copytree does not permit destination directory existence on py36. (on py38, it is OK to use dirs_exists_ok=True as the code before.)
Yes, I have confirmed the comment text you added.
After confirming, I thought that if "tmp_dir" was guaranteed to be unique, it wouldn't exist if you had to remove this empty directory "tmp_dir".
If my recognition is wrong, please point it out.

Just a question.
IMO, "tmp_dir" is a unique directory created by "tempfile.mkdtemp()" and is guaranteed to be unique, is it correct?
If it is correct, isn't "os.rmdir(tmp_dir)" unnecessary?
If it is not correct, isn't "os.rmdir(tmp_dir)" not enough and better to use "shutil.rmtree(tmp_dir)"?

> But copytree will fail if "tmp_dir" exists
see L.245 comment.

> IMO, "tmp_dir" is a unique directory created by "tempfile.mkdtemp()" and is guaranteed to be unique, is it correct?

correct. It is why mkdtemp() is used here.

> If it is correct, isn't "os.rmdir(tmp_dir)" unnecessary?
see the comment. The only reason why do rmdir is that copytree does not permit destination directory existence on py36. (on py38, it is OK to use dirs_exists_ok=True as the code before.)

I'm sorry, I misunderstood that "tempfile.mkdtemp" is not a function that creates a unique empty directory, but a function that gets a unique directory name.
There is no problem with the current implementation.

yes, "tmp_dir" was guaranteed to be unique and it is empty. But copytree will fail if "tmp_dir" exists. So it is necessary to rmdir before calling copytree. ("tmp_dir" will be made by copytree again, and it is expected to be unique.)

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hmm..we still use context.tenant_id everywhere. Could have also moved tenant to project_id from kwargs before calling the base __init__().

Locally tested with modified u-c file to use oslo.context 4.1.0

```
[tkajinam@mylaptop heat]$ grep -r oslo.context uc.txt 
oslo.context===4.1.0
[tkajinam@mylaptop heat]$ TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=uc.txt UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=uc.txt tox -e py38
...
  py38: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)
```

Ah ok. I understand that and we can implement a logic to deprecate tenant_id before removing it. This would help us to find out any remaining reference to that attribute before making breaking change.

Regarding the tenant attribute, the attribute was already deprecated even from heat RequestContext. There has been no implementation to override the attribute in heat RequestContext, thus access to the tenant attribute of heat RequestContext has been showing the deprecation warning implemented in oslo.context[1].

[1]
https://github.com/openstack/oslo.context/blob/stable/xena/oslo_context/context.py#L190
https://github.com/openstack/oslo.context/blob/stable/xena/oslo_context/context.py#L170

About the tenant attribute I'm removing now, the attribute was deprecated in oslo.context a long ago. Because heat RequestContext has been exposing the attribute directory, usage of the tenant attribute has been causing deprecation warning. So I'd say we've provided enough time until we actually drop the attribute.

By the way my understanding is that RequestContext class is designed as an internal class and is not really designed to be used by any external tooling. So deprecating attributes(for example tenant_id is now subject for removal) sounds overkill as long as we properly remove usage from heat itself.

Yes that's what I'm saying. We never moved from tenant to project. We probably should still use tenant with  heat RequestContext as we never deprecated it. Someone extending heat RequestContext would be broken.

tenant_id is not part of the base RequestContext in oslo.context but the additional argument in heat's own RequestContext.

https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/common/context.py#L137

In earlier version, I also tried replacing tenant_id but revert back that change to avoid mixing up two things. However I can submit a follow-up change to remove that as well.

That's part of heat-common package, so those theoretically can be used/extended as a library (don't know if someone is doing it). There is some history of it being not in sync with oslo.context. https://github.com/openstack/heat/commit/87a37f5db26b7cf6cc1e6240a7ebef4900983825

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Adding in the dnf stuff is fine.
the entire patch system is being re-written eventually for June, so this way we get the service running (even though it cant really be used) and the sm services, unlock etc.. will pass

I have a strong feeling dnf doesn't make any sense to be used, because we don't have an rpm based installation. 
Does it even list any package?

I'll use the assumption that cgcs-patch-agent is what we are targeting indeed since this change affects it. Then I think the service itself(cgcs-patch-agent) needs to be converted to use dpkg&co.

author.name: João Pedro Alexandroni Cordova de Sousa

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Just to clarify: We have the following 4 sevices:
- sw-patch
- sw-patch-agent
- sw-patch-controller
- sw-patch-controller-daemon

The dnf only affects the sw-patch-agent service. The others come up whitout it.

Most of this stuff(all?) is based on dnf and would not behave anyway since this is not an rpm based release -> having the software running does not help.
-> I think the easiest approach we could take is patch the service itself to be a dummy service that calls /bin/true, so it just runs.

The above assumes that sw-patch-agent is not needed to be live by other software( do hearthbeats, create files, etc...). We could explore this route.

author.name: João Pedro Alexandroni Cordova de Sousa

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
We discussed about it, since that was native for CentOS, but the point is that I think we wanted to go with something that would be quicker to be used on Debian, avoiding deeper changes and also having common code with CentOS. Modifying the service to use dpkg&co we would end up with 2 versions, one for each SO. Also, I believe changing it might need more extensive changes that simply a replace of tool. One option is to comment dnf out and just leave the service to come up, however, we tried doing that and could not make it work yet.
When commenting out dnf we had generic build errors appearing and we tried to fix those without much success, so we are still working on that, but it will take more time, maybe we should consider keeping dnf since the service will be non-funtional anyway.

Can you easily disable the dnf related code and remove any build deps on dnf? This would get the code in a position to be modified as needed without pulling in anything we don't want long term. 

If it's not easy, then as Al said, we just want the service running, so we can include dnf as a stop-gap and remove later.
Wouldn't it make more sense to add `neutron-vpnaas` to `pydep.txt` too?

debian-mirror-tools/config/debian/common.message:
I don't think adding dnf to a debian load serves a useful purpose.

Comment out the calls to dnf in some systematic way (# TODO: replace DNF) so that we can substitute calls to apt, dpkg or similar debian tools at a later date.

Adding the DNF packages, will allow the patch services resolve their missing imports and be able to startup even though they wont do anything.

This allows the Centos code to remain unchanged, while allowing the debian code, (which will not use DNF) to be able to start prototyping its conversion.

Once the changes for the Debian code is determined,  then these can be removed, the appropriate modules added, and the code can be structured to support divergent environments, and

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hi all,

I would appreciate it if you could take a look. This is a very large commit, but most of the changes consist of cherry-picked commits for the kernel.

Thank you!

Vefa
I see no issues with this. Once Jim is happy with things we can get this merged.

One thing I've never really understood is why, after the 5.10 yocto kernel was introduced with its nice git source repo (a luxury we never had with CentOS kernels), the maintainers continued to opt for additional kernel source patches instead of just maintaining commits on an stx branch in the source repo?  Eg. this would make a good stx dot release.  So basically why don't we have an stx clone of the yocto kernel, with our own branch hosting our own commits?  That would also save us all from hammering the yocto project's servers all the time, not to mention sped up kernel builds.  Just trying to understand, I must be missing something.....

Hi Jim,

Thanks for the feedback! I agree with your comment, especially because your suggestion would simplify life for me as well.

(Another approach to speed up the repository clone operation would be to download a tarball snapshot of the git tree, as is done for the Debian-based kernel builds in StarlingX currently, but this obviously does not have the advantage of using git.)

As mentioned above, I agree with you, but I was hoping that you could provide feedback about this specific patch :-) ... especially because the topic you bring up is not within my influence. :-/ As an example, I brought up the "slow clone" issue in a scrum meeting last week, but I was asked to hold off for now.

Let's discuss this topic internally with Mark Asselstine, maybe?

Thank you,

Vefa

All options are on the table. We needed to start somewhere to get going, but the ability to iterate and improve on the design is always open.

Sending patches to linux-yocto (the default Yocto Project kernel) should always be explored if the changes would benefit the Yocto Project. I would also be open to cloning linux-yocto to opendev and adding an stx (and stx-rt) branch(es). 

I agree dealing with patches in a 'git world' is not a long term solution.

kernel-modules/intel-ice/centos/ice-kmod.message: I'm kind of torn in both directions on this.  On the one hand, you're preserving the install behavior if auxiliary.ko got built.  But on the other hand this module should NOT be getting built anymore.  I lean towards removing this if block and the comment above it, unless you have a good reason to leave it in?

Thank you for the reminder. I have addressed this comment yesterday, but I have been having unrelated issues, hence the delays. Thankfully, my sanity-check build is about to finish, and I will publish a new version soon.
You have a good point. I do not have a good reason to keep the installation commands within a conditional statement. I will remove the reference to auxiliary.ko.
This is the only piece that I'm waiting on at this point.

kernel-rt/centos/kernel-rt.spec.message: Apparently I approved this patch name in the past?  <slaps himself> .  You don't need to rename this as it is not part of your work here.
I can address this with a separate commit.

Over time, as people just dump patches onto the end of the list, it can devolve into an unmaintainable hair-pulling mess.  My suggestion is to move any upstream commits to the beginning of the list where they can easily be dropped in the future.  I also recommend that long lists of patches that are bringing back a feature be placed in their own directory with name reflective of that feature eg. aux_bus/

But I won't hold you to this, just telling you what I would do if I was still lead maintainer of this stuff.  Feel free to just mark this resolved if you don't plan to move these patches in this review.

After second thought, given that this is purely housekeeping, let's not hold up your commit on it, but there really should be a work item to clean this up before it is allowed to get any worse.  Before you know it, 30 patches turn into 60 patches...
No problem! I will ask Mark about this during the next scrum meeting.

Thanks for the feedback! I agree that we should start to separate patches into categories, and the ordering can be improved as well. (By categories, I meant to refer to patches cherry-picked from upstream, local patches, and others I cannot think of now.)

Regarding the use of sub-directories, my only concern is that maintenance actions such as applying and/or regenerating patches become less straightforward on the command line. As an example, currently I can apply all patches to a repository using "git am .../*.patch", and I can regenerate all patches with "git format-patch --no-numbered -o .../patch_dir/  @{u}..HEAD". However, if we use sub-directories, applying patches would probably be somewhat straightforward, but generating patches into separate sub-directories with proper numbering (so that each sub-directory has patches starting from "0001") will become more complicated to automate -- it will not be a single command, at least. (Another option would be to not attempt to make the patches in each sub-directory start from "0001". Perhaps that would work.)

Would something like the following be acceptable to you? To help separate patches into categories, we can start prefixing commit subjects with the keyword "LOCAL:" (or something else) for all local patches, whereas subjects of patches from upstream would stay the same. If needed, we can add more keywords in the future. As an example, I recall that Ubuntu uses the "SAUCE:" prefix for various local changes. (Link: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Kernel/Dev/StablePatchFormat )

As mentioned above, I can also re-order the patches using the sorting criteria you described.

I can prepare a base commit that introduces a new organization scheme, and then rebase this commit onto that new base commit, as a start. Would that be okay with you?

To avoid going back and forth a lot, would you like to have a call about this?

Thanks again!

All good points. Backports, especially clean ones should be applied first followed by other changes. I think we should definitely plan and execute on creating a fork of linux-yocto and adding a stx branch to avoid 'live' patching. And also very important we need to constantly work to get patches applied where they make the most sense, so sending changes to linux-yocto when it makes sense.

I would prefer to explore dealing with git commits over managing directories.

I kind of object to swift being the default given a solid half of our issues are reported by "standalone users" who are not using swift. This just adds an additional configuration burden to be aware of which makes the software harder to use if we ship it with such a default moving forward.

the reason why I chose swift is because there is [redfish]use_swift=true that is used by virtual media. It would be better that by default every feature uses the same location - be it swift/http or smth else.

zuul.d/project.yaml.message:
I wouldn't move this, I don't understand the rationale.

I prefer having the check and the gate job definitions in one place.

@rodolfo mainly wanted to keep the layout file clean(avoid injecting long list of irrelevant files here) + also want to get these jobs running when we change the overrides in future but skip other jobs.
We already using many project-templates, also we don't manage definition of the tox jobs just do override them for our needs and to get future changes to these jobs and pipelines efficient, some examples of future patches:-
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/830812
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/827302
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/830623

past patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/819201 which took much time to get in, there can be many such examples.
I understand Rodolfo's point here, but we discussed it offline too and I'm going to approve this patch. It still seems to be small improvement in terms of the overall infra resources' usage :)

<< We use templates from other projects but not from Neutron. I don't see the benefit of, a part from the external templates, why should we define the list of jobs in two different places. The size of this file is short enough to be manageable.

It's not about size at all, it's all about optimization as shared in previous comments. I have seen many patches in past adjusting these, for tox jobs adjusting timeouts is example and from periodic,experimental addition/removing of jobs. And all these changes are recurring so i think it's good to improve it and thus this patch.

<< I prefer to have all CI queue definitions in one single place.
We can never have that unless we stop using templates altogether, We currently don't have queue definition at single place(we using templates from other projects, this one proposing to move not all but some special(periodic/expeimental as have different triggers then check/cage, tox for the overrides of jobs from other project) jobs to a template and different file)
Yes if it's possible to get same benefits by keeping in single place i will too prefer that, but i don't see how it can be done without losing coverage for check/gate jobs, if you or others have some idea for that? i can consider working on that.

<< None of the referred patches are affected by this patch, it is not optimizing the code.
Yes right it's not code optimization but reducing CI time(less jobs) + people(committers to these jobs and reviewers to these jobs) time(less unnecessary jobs would lead to avoid failures in that, check logs and re-check to rerun), and yes this is not solving all the problems but 1 of them. All the patches linked are related in terms of optimization mentioned, and these are just example there are lot of such which can be found out.

We use templates from other projects but not from Neutron. I don't see the benefit of, a part from the external templates, why should we define the list of jobs in two different places. The size of this file is short enough to be manageable.

I prefer to have all CI queue definitions in one single place.

None of the referred patches are affected by this patch, it is not optimizing the code.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This is not what we do atm. We don't allow project-admins to do stack operations across all projects in a deployment. So option 4[1] is not relevant for us.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html#listing-project-resources-across-the-deployment

Blocking till we understand the consequences of changing the existing behavior.

My understanding is that option 4 is now general approach for step 1 implementation as is documented in the last sentence.
~~~
The direction for Phase 1 is to use solution #4, where a project-admin can continue listing resources across the deployment, while we target domain support for Phase 2 or Phase 3.
~~~

For example now Nova nova allows project-admins to list instances.

So the problem here is that heat historically never allowed project-admins to list all resources(the policy rule for that API was DENY_EVERYONE previously), and the main question is whether we want to "loose" access control about that API.

I've updated the commit message based on my latest understanding.

Heat already allowed project admins to list stacks in all projects by list stacks api. This is not "added" by this change but just is kept[1]. I hope now that is more clearly and accurately explained.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/b1fe9752b0e03a6036e7fde8312a8e0e80e297f9/heat/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L716

What this change drops is the access to project resources like stack or resource using system scope. This is backword incompatible but considering the status(and the existing change in the other projects), it's reasonable to skip redundant deprecation for "experimental" system-scoped rules.

Hmm, I think I didn't explain it well and also was confused with the current description of the spec.

Nova used to allow project admins to list servers for all tenants. According to the initial design of SRBAC the change was made to allow system users to use that API, but that was recently reverted back to follow the updated design of SRBAC[1]. When I made the previous comment I was referring to the fact Nova switched back to project-scope from system-scope but was not much care about the previous policy rule which allows project-admin.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/816206

We should revert the policy rule back to DENY_EVERYONE in this case as heat never allowed usage of that API before SRBAC was initially introduced ? As we do not intend to allow system users to use global listing, IMO we should update it to more "narrow" scope before cutting of Yoga release.

This becomes more like a side-topic but I initially selected project-scope because the current design of heat api doesn't allow usage of system scope/project scope credentials(unless we implement any workaround in client side), which I'm addressing in the subsequent patch.

Last sentence[1] says, "continue allowing", which we don't do atm.

I thought nova always allowed project-admins to list instances in all projects. What is the nova change we're referring to?

[1] The fourth solution would be to "continue allowing" people with the admin role on a project to list all resources across the deployment.

I thought stacks:global_index is the only policy affecting global indexing but I noticed context_is_admin is also used as a key to determine whether global listing is allowed. I'll recheck that to find out what I need to additionally fix.

Regarding the backword incompatibility, yes. This change breakes the new policy rules for SRBAC while I intend to keep the deprecated rules. This follows the existing "revert" patches in nova and neutron and AFAIK SRBAC is still in a kind of experimental phase and I don't see much benefit with deprecating the new rules to revert them to the old rules.

> We should revert the policy rule back to DENY_EVERYONE

Which policy? We had the policy (RULE_DENY_STACK_USER) to allow everyone other than stack user (in-instance users defined in stack templates which are assigned the heat_stack_user role that's allowed to use DescribeStackResource).

There is an additional check to allow "admin in admin project" to access all stacks in deployments.

The assumption of those new policies added is that "admin role in admin project" is now the new SYSTEM_ADMIN (admin user with system scoped token)?.

I guess some of the changes you're suggesting are backward incompatible.

heat/policies/base.py.message: We can keep this because we also have additional policy rules to enforce project scope in each API.

heat/policies/stacks.py.message: This results in extending scope. I think reverting this back to DENY_EVERYONE is the right direction.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
We have a few partitioning schemes that are required for StarlingX. The current one maps to AIO-SX where we initially provision a minimally sized layout that is compliant for ansible/puppet bootstrap configuration. Additional partitioning schemes will be provided with full kickstart integration.

We do not want to autofill the last partition in this scenario. We want to provide as much free space as possible for customer provisioning in single disk configurations.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Tested with on our centos 8 stream host, seems ok, thanks Steve!

I'm not sure about these footgun fixes in general. Why on earth was libvirt installed on the UC int the first place?

Kevin's suggestion on masking the service makes sense.
Let's say customer deploy a RHEL server with GDM and libvirtd is installed and enabled by default in those groups ?   I think this is 99% of the ~50 cases we got in the past few cycles.

+1 to what Harald said in chat. Effectively run two tasks: ensure the service is stopped if it's actually installed and always mask the server to ensure it is never started even if it is installed out-of-band.

I'm struggling as to why we need a new service to disable/mask libvirt.

For new installs, they won't have libvirt.
For upgrades, can't we just use the existing UndercloudUpgrade service?

What is the intent here? Just to prevent accidental install of libvirt at a later date? I don't think we need to add handling for that, and would instead prefer this to be implemented as an undercloud validation if that is the motivation.
So, we need to validate this before doing anything and raise an Error. 👍

this is exactly the case for a validation. same as if there isn't enough disk space. we shouldn't try to mask or hide that issue. what if the customer has installed virt-manager for a specific reason? i'm not a fan of just masking out critical services on the RHEL node they've chosen to install the undercloud. They've clearly made a wrong choice...we need to surface that.

I agree with James. 

I can imagine a junior sysadmin tasked with installing an undercloud, he/she is told to install it on host kvm-13. Junior sysadmin fail to realize the undercloud should be a VM on host kvm-13 and install the undercloud on kvm-13 ... boom libvirt stops and business is interupted because kvm-13 stopped working. Junior sysadmin looses confidence and does not go on to do great things.

Let's raise the issue to the user instead of hiding it and potentially cause other problems.

We'll move all the other place where we stop/disable/mask libvirt under tripleo_ansible too but we need to make sure dnsmasq / libvirtd is not running on the undercloud.   Troubleshooting those issues generates some cases that would've been avoided if we did this from the beginning.   libvirtd can't be running on a node where you install the undercloud otherwise introspection will break.  This is not an upgrade but an installation issue.  Users will just install tripleo-client on a RHEL Server with virt-manager installed along with libvirtd , GDM anx X11 .   We could've avoided a bunch of user issues with this ... along in the overcloud controllers where sometimes users will have pre-provisionned nodes where libvirtd is installed.   It adds hours of useless troubleshooting that could've been avoided by handling those issues in the installer.
If a junior sysadmin installs the undercloud on that node and it goes up to that point, the node is dead anyways. ;)

deployment/undercloud/undercloud-install.message: Should we do "rpm -q --whatprovides libvirt-daemon" here, in case there is ever a wrapper RPM?

I copy/pasted this code from 2 other deployment files already present in tht... would "--whatprovides" change something to "-q" alone or would it just return the name of the package wrapping that libvirt-daemon package like "libvirtd" but either ones works ?  Sorry I'm not dnf/rpm expert here.

As a host prep-task interacting with systemd is there a potential here for a race? If so, I think we can do this and fallback to some sort of a systemd override which can be dropped at any time and force libvirt to never start when running on the undercloud.

I don't get what's different here beside that you splitted the "- name: make sure libvirt services are disabled and masked" section into 2  ... if it's installed, we mask, disable and stop it .    In your example, in the first section you just make sure it's not enabled and masked ... if it's installed then you stop it ... but it's masked ?   What's wrong with the code on the right side ?  It's the same code being used in 2 other deployment files that I just re-used.

To ensure everything is masked, and not started, and not started should libvirt be installed on the undercloud at a later date, I think we should do something like this::


      host_prep_tasks:
        - name: make sure libvirt services are disabled and masked
          service:
            name: "{{ item }}"
            enabled: false
            masked: true
            daemon_reload: true
          loop:
            - libvirtd.service
            - virtlogd.socket
        - name: check if libvirt is installed
          command: /usr/bin/rpm -q libvirt-daemon
          failed_when: false
          register: libvirt_installed
          check_mode: false
        - name: make sure libvirt services are disabled and masked
          service:
            name: "{{ item }}"
            state: stopped
          loop:
            - libvirtd.service
            - virtlogd.socket
          when:
            - libvirt_installed.rc == 0

I think Kevin's idea is that even if libvirt is not installed, we mask the service.
So that if someone does 'dnf install libvirt' or 'group install "Virtualization Host", the services are "pre-masked" so they won't start?

I'm not 100% sure if masking the service will work when the packages are not present. If it does, it seems like a good idea?

[root@overcloud-controller-0 etc]# systemctl mask asdf
Unit asdf.service does not exist, proceeding anyway.
Created symlink /etc/systemd/system/asdf.service → /dev/null.


that would depend if it over write the file or not.

The 'disabled by default' part needs to be communicated well.

I can foresee folks adding new upstream packages that provide services, and being puzzled why the service isn't available.
Wouldn't be better to add this on the systemd-config scope, using the override locations for the package: /etc/systemd/system-preset?

We are adding it here for now to support integration activities as this package is helping identify specific compatibility issues while we are maintaining both OSes. Eventually the package should go away as when we drop CentOS and optimize for Debian. 

I can see 99-default-disable.preset and 90-default.preset moving to systemd-config and 85-debpkg-issues disappearing.

We will need to enable a set if services based on personality trait during kickstart/initial boot as all packages will be installed for all personalities.

For now we are focused on enabling AIO specific packaging.

Just curious. I have moved my laptop to run Debian Bullseye

masselst@yow-masselst-lx1:/tmp/ostree$ ls -ld /usr/include/config
ls: cannot access '/usr/include/config': No such file or directory
masselst@yow-masselst-lx1:/tmp/ostree$ ls -ld /usr/include/linux 
drwxr-xr-x 28 root root 61440 Jan 23 15:16 /usr/include/linux

is my base directory incorrect?

@Vefa correct.  I asked in the debian channel on Wednesday and was told that include/config is where Debian puts kernel headers and mentioned that I thought it was weird that it uses a dir named config.  Charles Short, who is familiar with Debian, told me it was normal.
Yup. So my base directory was incorrect. Thanks for the follow-up.

Hi Mark,

With Jim's change, I think the variable LINUX_INCLUDE_DIR is referring to the
```
/usr/src/linux-headers-<kver>/include/config
```
directory, but I might be incorrect. The config directory is where the kernel's build system produces its kconfig related files.

Here is how it looks like on a random Ubuntu-based system:

```
$ ls  /usr/src/linux-headers-5.13.0-30-generic/include/config/ | head
104_QUAD_8
60XX_WDT
64BIT
6LOWPAN
6LOWPAN_NHC
6LOWPAN_NHC_DEST
6LOWPAN_NHC_FRAGMENT
6LOWPAN_NHC_HOP
6LOWPAN_NHC_IPV6
6LOWPAN_NHC_MOBILITY
# ...
```

Looking at this script in more detail, it is checking that the include/linux (or after this patch, the include/config) *directory* exists, to determine the base directory /usr/src/linux-headers-<kver>, from which then it looks for auxiliary_bus.h in the ${ksrc} directory.

Here is how the ${ksrc} variable is set:

```
find_kernel_source()
{
        # All the default places to look for kernel source
        test_dirs=(/lib/modules/${build_kernel}/source \
                   /lib/modules/${build_kernel}/build \
                   /usr/src/linux-${build_kernel} \
                   /usr/src/linux-$(echo ${build_kernel} | sed 's/-.*//') \
                   /usr/src/kernel-headers-${build_kernel} \
                   /usr/src/kernel-source-${build_kernel} \
                   /usr/src/linux-$(echo ${build_kernel} | sed 's/\([0-9]*\.[0-9]*\)\..*/\1/') \
                   /usr/src/linux \
                   /usr/src/kernels/${build_kernel} \
                   /usr/src/kernels)

        # Save the first valid kernel source path
        for dir in "${test_dirs[@]}"; do
                if [ -d ${dir}/${LINUX_INCLUDE_DIR} ]; then
                        ksrc=${dir}
                        break
                fi
        done
        # ...
```

Here is how the ${ksrc} variable is used:

```
find_aux_bus_inc()
{
        aux_bus_inc=$(find -L ${ksrc} -name "auxiliary_bus.h")
        msg "auxiliary_bus.h location: ${aux_bus_inc}"
}
```

All this to say, we ideally should not need to modify this file, because /usr/src/linux-headers-<kver>/include/linux should exist on the build system as a directory, too.

Thanks for posting something specific that we can criticize. 😊  Some observations inline.  I'll have to see what the Cinder project team thinks about it.

I don't like this idea. Basically, this means that for half of the release, we will care less about quality. We should therefore either choose to stay as we are, or move to a 1 year cadence. I'm opinionated toward the later.

If we are to have this proposal move forward, what about having a "tick" every 4 releases? From the distribution point of view, this makes some kind of "LTS" releases, that we can upgrade to, without using the intermediary releases. This fits perfectly the Ubuntu and Debian release model (which is aligned on a 2 years release cycle). Having a "tick" every year doesn't address the main concern of upgradability from the distribution point of view.

> I don't like this idea. Basically, this means that for half of the release, we will care less about quality. 

I don't think this says that *at all*. Quality has to remain at least where it is today, as we continue testing upgrades in the same way between each adjacent release. This doesn't remove any restrictions, or make the tock releases less important. It purely removes the ability to do things that assume you're only upgrading from the previous release. If anything, it requires a more holistic view of upgrade-related things to consider a wider window. To me, that's *higher* quality, not *lower*.

> If we are to have this proposal move forward, what about having a "tick" every 4 releases? From the distribution point of view, this makes some kind of "LTS" releases, that we can upgrade to, without using the intermediary releases. This fits perfectly the Ubuntu and Debian release model (which is aligned on a 2 years release cycle). Having a "tick" every year doesn't address the main concern of upgradability from the distribution point of view.

I'm not sure how to reconcile "one tick-tock makes quality lower" but "two makes quality higher". However, a one-year tick-tock gives us additional functionality without a major change to what we're currently doing. If it is too difficult for too little gain, we can just drop the tick-tock meaning and continue doing what we were doing (unlike an actual change to the cycle length). If it is beneficial, and the tock releases become unimportant, we can drop them and fall back to a single release per year. If everything is useful, we could move to one tick for every four as you describe. However, I think moving to any of those eventualities immediately will be too destabilizing and severe of a change right off the line.
(Despite the above concerns, I think this is a great step forward, not backward.)

Considering what Dan Smith replied to me (ie: that the current tick-tock thingy is a nice step forward, going on the direction of a 2 years thingy), I change my mind and approve.

Hopefully, after a few tick-tock cycle, everyone will be confident to move this to a tick-tock-tock-tock cycle! 😊
I think this is well written and explains things pretty well.  Thanks Dan!

Looks good to me.
I believe this proposal is a great move forward for the release cadence and it attends to the most community concerns.

Ok, then I'm going to rephrase, since I got the wrong comment on my comment, hoping to make it more clear...

It is my opinion that offering the possibility to skip just *one* release isn't useful from the downstream distribution point of view (ie: Debian & Ubuntu), and it will only make things more complicated upstream. Having the possibility to skip 3 (and have a 2 years release cycle aligned with the distros) would be VERY nice.

From the operator perspective, skipping one is probably easier, when one wants to upgrade from N to N+2, because of not having to go through N+1. But that's kind of a very limited improvement. What would help is a LTS release that would be supported for longer time (like: if the last tick release every 4 releases was supported for 3 or 4 years, for example, matching what we do in distributions).

I'm very aware that what I'm saying is difficult to achieve upstream, especially when dealing with the CI, and back-porting patches. But if we want an improvement from the user perspective, that's what we need to do. Doing the tick-tock thingy as proposed isn't improving anything: neither from the user perspective, neither from the upstream point of view. It just make db migrations more difficult to maintain upstream.

I'm therefore still voting against...

Sorry for late reaction, please find my inline comments.

And also one general comment - would TC allow select projects to only release ticks?

Yes, I think "between tick and tock" doesn't convey direction as much as something like "from tick to tock", but I'll add something here.

When is it? I mean it isn't obvious to the reader here 😊

We have three deprecation related guidelines:

minor changes happening at the beginning of a cycle -- 1 cycle deprecation, support can be dropped in the next release

major changes happening at the beginning of a cycle -- 2 cycle deprecation, support can be dropped at the beginning of the third release

minor/major changes happening at the end of a cycle -- add one cycle to the above guidance

FFU upgrade steps by deployers so far have accommodated these models. 

Would we redo these guidelines to specify that only tick releases are considered while waiting/performing removals?

i.e., 

if minor deprecation occurs at the beginning of a tick, wait until next tick for removal (i.e., support something for two cycles: tick, tock)
if major deprecation occurs at the beginning of a tick, perform removal at the beginning of the third tick (i.e., support something for 4 normal cycles: tick, tock, tick, tock)

Yes, I think the simplest way to put this is "the same rules as today in terms of deprecation cycle, except only "tick" releases count.

I can see it being useful to also say that you can't start a deprecation in a tock release if the signal comes only there and only through a reno, as people only running tick releases might never see them. I'll try to add some words.

Thanks, that's a good explanation.
I think not requiring live upgrades to be supported may effectively render this proposal useless for deployers because they, nonetheless, prepare to avoid downtime, not embrace it.

Nobody currently doing FFU is able to do them live. So my feeling is that anyone interested in only deploying tick releases is already doing a not-live upgrade, and thus this shouldn't be any sort of regression for them. It brings the benefit of not having to step through the tock releases and thus makes it more likely to stay current.

Of course, we must crawl before we walk - nothing here prevents live from working, now or in the future, but as many projects can't even do live upgrades I think requiring it would basically be impossible at the moment.

What do you mean? If we don't do a multinode grenade job where we leave behind some of the services, then we won't get stuck if we were to break this capability. In terms of upgrade practicalities, it should be the same as FFU today without the intermediate steps. Any operator currently hopping between non-adjacent releases using FFU (or luck) is already having to shut down services so they don't have very old things running together with new ones.

I think it's fine to say that if you want live upgrades, you should stick to the 6-month releases, as you must today. Whether or not we expand our promises to include live support from tick-to-tick (which is a pretty big ask) can be left for the future.

-1: I think we should add the details of how this affects online data migrations.

With our current upgrade support (both rolling and FFU) we don't need to keep online data migrations from the previous release around, so they are removed from the code on each release, but with this new approach we need to keep a part of them around for tick-to-tick upgrades.

So the online data migration code that is run while the services run can be removed, but the code from the previous release that is run on the manage commands (i.e., cinder-manage db online_data_migrations) needs to be kept around for tick releases (so it has the tock migration).

These tock data migrations need to be moved so they are run in the "db sync" command and they must be run **before** the tick db schema changes happen, otherwise we could be losing data.

An example of how we would be losing is when renaming a column. With the current mechanism it would go like this:

- Tick#1 is released (N release): DB schema migration creates new column in DB table with online data migration code in manage and service.

- Tick#1 is installed: DB schema creates the new column

- Tick#1 is running for a while: Online data migration code running on the services copies the data from old column to the new one and to keeps them in sync for **resources** that are accessed.

- Tock#1 is released (N+1 release): Online data migrations code is removed and  project code stops using old column.

- Tick#2 is released (N+2 release): DB schema migration drops old column.

- Upgrade from Tick#1 to Tick#2: When Tick#2 DB schema migration is run it deletes the old column and any resource that had not being accessed while Tick#1 was running will either have an empty new column or will crash because the column is set to no longer be nullable.

> An example of how we would be losing is when renaming a column. With the current mechanism it would go like this:

I'm not sure the above example is complete, because nothing in tock #1 describes migrating all the resources that don't get touched during normal activity, which is what your tick-tick failure scenario describes. However, the above describes dropping online migration code in a tock, which is what this resolution describes as "not okay" for the reason you describe here. I think that in any scenario like you describe, you need to have something to ensure that all the resources get migrated, to cover the inactive ones, and that can happen in the background in tick #1. In nova we usually provide a nova-manage command to push batches of those inactive resource migrations that the operator can run after upgrade at idle time. given that example, you can still "stop using the old column" in tock #1, and you can still drop the migration code in tick #1 along with the column itself, if you want. I think it's fine to tell operators that they have to have "finished all their homework" from tick #1 before they can upgrade to tick #2, and that's usually how we describe it in Nova.

That said, as you note, this resolution clearly adds some additional accounting for these upgrade things, which will be extra work, no doubt about it. I just think it's a very manageable amount of additional work with minimal actual change to how things work.

Ok, thanks for the writeup, I understand it even better now and suggest we simply add ", as it is done today for upgrades between major versions."

Ack, perhaps just the wording here could change (if needed). It's not a new requirement, just noting how this has to be done in general.

Using nova as an example, already today when we do an online data migration, we generally have the code migrate things from an old format to a new format when they're touched. Meaning if we need to update the way we store an instance, if we read that instance, we save it back to the DB in the new format. Thus, these things get migrated at runtime as they're used. However, it's totally possible that a long-lived instance could be untouched for a year and thus never have had an opportunity to be opportunistically migrated in the DB. If we were to then remove code that allows for the old format, we'd be in trouble. As such, we also generally provide tooling that will run through and "touch" everything in the DB to make sure it gets that opportunity, either manually-executed by the operator, or some very slow background task that attempts to do it automatically.

That's already how it works today, and is required for anyone trying to do this sort of thing where they want to deprecate the older schema/format and ultimately remove the code that provides that compatibility. So the point of this bullet, as added at the request of Gorka for clarity, is just that anyone doing this sort of thing in a tock release would need to make sure that operators have run that manual process before upgrading from tick to another tick, if the tock release is where they drop that support. It's the same as it is today, but with the assumption that nobody can possibly skip those releases anyway. For people doing FFUs, they often have to either run each intermediate release for a period of time to allow those migrations to happen, or run the manual tooling from those releases before moving to the next step. Eliminating that requirement (only for tock releases) is a major benefit to those people, and all it requires for the projects is to know that they can't introduce some migration process only in a tock release, which could be skipped by people.

That's a lot of words, but hopefully it makes sense. I think to anyone who currently orchestrates this sort of thing, it does, and as Gorka noted, he just wanted it to be called out specifically.

Their data sources are the same, but ``created_vim_info`` only has the contents of the vim table. And ``get_vim`` has the contents of vim and vimauths table. The following processing needs to use the auth_url field in the vimauths table.

Maybe we can remove this var by making this block a method.

Please check the following a pseudo code. 

```
        def get_or_create_vim(context, vim_name, server):
            created_vim_info = self._get_vim_by_name(context, vim_name)
            if created_vim_info:
                vim_info = self.nfvo_plugin.get_vim(context, created_vim_info['id'])
                if (vim_info['auth_url'] == server and
                    created_vim_info.get('status') == 'REACHABLE'):
                    return created_vim_info
            try:
                return nfvo_plugin.create_vim(context, vim_info)
            except Exception as e:
                LOG.error("Failed to register kubernetes vim: %s" % e)

```

Reading the ll.339-430, it seems that if ``master_vm_dict_list`` is NOT empty, ``vm_dict`` always has the key ``ssh`` and ``nic_ip``.
Thus, we don't have to do ``get('ssh')`` and ``get('nic_ip')`` here.
Also, you do ``nic_ip.split('.')[-1]`` just below this line, which will cause an error if ``nic_ip`` is None even if doing ``get('nic_ip')`` here. 

It's just a minor comment so you can ignore it, but I think it's ideally better to make ``vm_dict`` a class so that you can add any property to get an attribute easily. 
Something like this.

```
class VM:
    ...

    @property
    def nic_ip(self):
        return self._ssh['nic_ip']
        
    @property
    def master_name(self):
        return 'master' + self.nic_ip.split('.')[-1]

vm = VM(username, password, ipaddr, nic_ip)
print(vm.nic_ip)
# Output: 192.168.0.1

```

environments/services/undercloud-remove-.message: Can we add this to environments/undercloud.yaml instead of creating a new file ? I feel like this is the reasonable default in undercloud since all nova services are disabled by default.

The cleanup tasks are implemented in upgrade_tasks, thus are run only by undercloud upgrade. These tasks are not executed by undercloud deploy. We've been using undercloud upgrade for minor update actually but these task should be idempotent and there is no harm even if we run them during minor update.

Looking at the current implementation for novajoin, we have a separate environment to disable service. However includes the environment for undercloud deploy/upgrade thus this does effectively same as overriding the resource in undercloud.yaml. IMO this is very redundant and makes our future maintenance just complicated.
So do I have to adjust anything here?
I think no, since that would call that service for regualar deployments as well, while we want it only for upgrades

environments/undercloud.yaml.message: Should this be added only for upgrade to remove required containers?

This requires defines only upgrade_tasks, which means it is used only by undercloud upgrade. The clean up tasks are not executed by the install command.

One limitation is that we run the clean up tasks during minor update because we use the same upgrade command for both minor update and major upgrade but the clean up tasks should be independent and I'm not aware of any risk with running the task during update.

can we add these upgrade_tasks to the UndercloudUpgrade service instead? that's basically what that is for. lots of cleanup stuff there already. in fact, we could cleanup some of that cleanup since it would have already been executed on everyone's undercloud.

for a new deployment, "UndercloudRemoveNova" service is not required. by having it in the common environment, the service is deployed but does nothing, any upgrade in such environments, will run the upgrade tasks, which does nothing as those services are not present. It would have been ideal if this service is added for upgrade and not for new deployment. 

If it is not possible, I am fine with the current approach.

> this be added only for upgrade to remove required containers?

that was my original intention, see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/827261

The decision was to move the logic here

manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/admin/tes.message: I am confused how this test will pass in stable/xena where the only_host filter doesn't exist...
Resolved with introducing a new API microversion
"Skipping" isn't necessary... when a skip exception is raised here, the word "SKIPPED" is added to the logs
For running multi-backend tests, two or more backend names must be configured

in addition, you need to set the max_api_microversion in the config to '2.67' as well, or these tests won't be run: https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/73e0b6fdc450b7539bf6a97349f5774177ffb24a/manila_tempest_tests/config.py#L42-L45


Take a look at one of the test jobs - the tests below don't show up there: https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_ea1/816168/5/check/manila-tempest-plugin-dummy-no-dhss/ea111f4/testr_results.html

Testing of replication is disabled by default configuration here since it is an optional feature for share backends to support.

So, you'll need to skip this test unless replication is enabled; example: https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/86f2432476ba9128bb2c26a78ae3b3f53327d4bd/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_revert_to_snapshot.py#L151-L152

don't you want to make sure your replica goes to the other available backend and not the one in which the source/"active" replica is?

Manila won't let you create a replica in the same host.. (you *might* be able to create a replica in a different pool in the same host, but, that's up to the scheduler's decision).. 


Here's an example of a test that gets the available hosts (pools) filtered by the share's host's replication domain: https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/86f2432476ba9128bb2c26a78ae3b3f53327d4bd/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_replication.py#L239 - maybe you could use that to find a pool to set as "only_host"

To create a replica of a share, the share's type must have a "replication_type" extra-spec set. The share type associated with this class isn't requesting it; so this will fail. 

Please see https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/86f2432476ba9128bb2c26a78ae3b3f53327d4bd/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_revert_to_snapshot.py#L159-L170 for an example of how to create:

1) a share type that supports replication, based off of the "backend_replication_type" config parameter
2) a share with that share type
3) a share replica

the call you need here is to the client's get_share_replica method: https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/98b3e8782d20d193974173c5763236bb0478a289/manila_tempest_tests/services/share/v2/json/shares_client.py#L1547-L1557

Listing share replicas would include "active" and other replica ("in-sync" or "out-of-sync") copies -- so this wouldn't be a deterministic way to get information about the replica you just created

This got quite complicated... setting up resources in the class's resource_setup isn't always necessary - it makes things easier if you have multiple tests that can share some resources.. that isn't the case here - the share you're creating in the setup method is only being used by one of the tests.. it feels like you can make things more readable/simple if you created shares in the test - i.e., when you need them.. 

suggestions in follow up comments below..

create the share type right here; and since this test is only executed if replication is enabled, you don't need any conditionals; also we don't need any other capabilities that we're not testing here.. 


        def test_only_host_scheduler_hint_in_share_replica_creation(self):
            replication_type = CONF.share.backend_replication_type
            if replication_type not in constants.REPLICATION_TYPE_CHOICES:
                raise share_exceptions.ShareReplicationTypeException(
                    replication_type=cls.replication_type
                )
            extra_specs = cls.add_extra_specs_to_dict({
                "replication_type": replication_type
            })
            replicated_share_type = self.create_share_type(
                data_utils.rand_name("replicated-shares"),
                extra_specs=extra_specs)
            share = self.create_share(
                 share_type_id=self.replicated_share_type['id'],
                 cleanup_in_class=False)
            share = self.admin_client.get_share(share['id'])['share']
            share_host = share['host']

            rep_domain, pools = self.get_pools_for_replication_domain()
            if len(pools) < 2:
               msg = ("Cannot test scheduler hints with replication due to insuffcient pools.")
            raise self.skipException(msg)
    
            for p in pools:
               if p['name'] != share_host:
                expected_replica_host = p['name']
                scheduler_hint = {"only_host": "%s" % backend_to_verify}
                break

           replica = self.create_share_replica(share['id'],
                                            cleanup_in_class=False,
                                            version=LATEST_MICROVERSION,
                                            scheduler_hints=scheduler_hint)
           replica = self.admin_client.get_share_replica(
            replica['id'])['share_replica']
       
           replica_host = replica['host']

            # verify same backends
            self.assertEqual(expected_replica_host, actual_replica_host)

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Some random thoughts:

I have been feeling unsure about proxying quota update APIs to keystone now, as I've started working on tempest tests.

I think the challenge with not proxying is that it looks like users can update quotas in horizon:

https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/admin/set-quotas.html

and if we didn't proxy, we'd have to coordinate and update horizon to call keystone instead. But horizon would also need to be able to discover whether nova is configured with unified limits in order to know what to do.

Maybe that's why we arrived at going ahead to proxy to keystone for updates ... because updating things like horizon would be easier when unified limits is no longer a choice and it's the only way to do quotas in nova.

nova/quota.py.message: OK, so this is the new method that will return a limit of 0 for a project limit if the user has not set a project limit in keystone, and intends to only rely on the default (registered) limit.

Then this logic is saying, for all resources passed in, if the resource is in keystone_limits (which it will be, because in the case of limit._LimitNotFound we will get a limit of 0) then use the keystone limit, else use the local limit and if that isn't found, use unlimited -1.

AFAICT, we will never hit the else branch here, right? We'll never not have a resource in keystone_limits because not found limits will be returned as 0 (see my comment on L820).

So we'll never fall back on the local_limits. I assume that's not intended? And if it's not intended, this is highlighting some missing test coverage that we need. :(

So we do test this, for things like "security_group_rules", it returns "-1. This is because the resources passed in include: keystone limits, local imits and deprecated limits.

This is super unclear, I will add some comments.
Sorry, why would this default to -1 for usage? Should be 0 right?
Also something that should be covered in test coverage (did I miss it?)

Its in the tests, you see -1 for the security_group rules. This was to keep it the same as the no op driver.

But checking the tests, we should move that to the default for the db driver, given that is what most people who have quotas on want the API to stay the same to. Sounds more sensible, as you note.
Ack

Note to reviewers: this change makes it so that cores/ram/instances default to a limit of 0 if they are not found in keystone. Prior to this line, cores/ram/instances were defaulting to -1 unlimited as they were not being pulled from keystone limits yet.
Ack

ah, I think you are correct

Yeah, so this should mention that if no project limit is set, and no registered limit is set, we tell the API the limit is 0, because that is how oslo-limit deals with this situation.

I'm wondering about the effect of this on the scenario where there are default limits but no project limits set. If there is not a project limit set, the default limit should be used. If we fill in a limit of 0 here, wouldn't that override the default limit and be incorrect?
sorry, _get_limit actually checks project and registered limits, so 0 only when neither are set, my comment and method name is very missleading here.
This is used by the API. The way oslo.limit is implemented you can't create any instances, i.e. the limit is 0.

OK, I looked at the code so I understand:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.limit/blob/485c770abf768383277c55f09146da0528c06953/oslo_limit/limit.py#L242

So you chose to call _get_limit instead of _get_project_limit so you could know if a limit has not been set either at the default level or at the project level.

The thing that seems wrong to me is that in the next patch, there's fallback logic for using local_limits if we don't have keystone_limits for a given resource, but AFAICT that logic will never be reached. See:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/713499/6/nova/quota.py@826

Aside, I think all of these could majorly use some code comments. Quotas are complicated IMHO and I think we would all appreciate more prose around here explaining what is happening and what's intended.

The return value of this function is not an integer, it's a openstacksdk RegisteredLimit object [1]. So this needs to be instead:

 max = limit_utils._get_registered_limit(new_name).default_limit

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.limit/blob/0820b8c38f92037592040c1215b4ec5e2d9f672c/oslo_limit/limit.py#L270

Which works for me in glance locally.

Also, we really need to fix oslo.limit to expose this stuff properly (as the comment says).

John, do you have work started on this already? If not, I might get started on it. Glance has no API for exposing quota stats (because it currently has no quotas) but obviously exposing what the limit is for a user (registered or actual) is going to be something we need in order to expose usage info like that.
Done

I guess I should have been more explicit and said: mocking the internals of oslo.limit like this make this sort of bug a real danger. In glance, I tried to stick to mocking the keystone client API in order to make sure our interface with oslo.limit was mostly intact (although I copied the enforcement model mock from oslo.limit's own tests). releasenotes/notes/add-volume-re-image-a.message: this needs to match what's in cinder/api/microversions.py

Query: and eventually after successful re-image, the state is reverted to previous i.e available/error/reserved ?
Sorry, if this sounds like dumb question.

When the volume is in available/error state, cinder can initiate the reimage operation which, if successful, will change the status to available.
When volume is in in-use state, mostly nova will initiate the operation, the volume will remain in reserved state throughout the operation and eventually the volume will again change to in-use state.

I suggest adding a paragraph here, something like:

Note that this is a destructive action, that is, all data currently contained in a volume is destroyed when the volume is re-imaged.

I think what's important in this final paragraph is to give the names of the policies and what actions they govern, something like

  Two new policies are introduced to govern this functionality:

  * ``policy_one`` - users who satisfy this policy may re-image a volume in
    status ``available`` or ``error``
  * ``policy_two`` - users who satisfy this policy may re-image a volume in
    status ``reserved``

  The default setting for both policies allow an administrator or the volume
  owner to perform the associated action.  See the `Policy configuration
  <https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/yoga/configuration/block-storage/policy.html>`_
  documentation in the `Cinder Service Configuration` guide for details.

(We want to be a bit vague about the definition because it will hopefully be different by RC-time.)

Also, I think you should add an "upgrade:" section to the note containing the same info; you can change the first sentence to something like:

  Two new policies are introduced to govern the volume reimage functionality
  introduced with microversion 3.68:

I attempted to justfy this in the spec, I guess I didn't do that well enough yet.

As an operator, I only care about the race for things that really use resources, i.e. things that are moving to oslo.limit based enforement.

Given these are demoted to config options, I drop the re-check here. The race, while possible, is a very small window here, and doesn't really matter all that much. If it really mattered, we should move it into unified limits.

Is this just one REST call to keystone or N (limits)? If it's N, I think we should have a way to only grab the limits we need. Though, as I say that, I think implementing a batch call in keystone would be better actually.

I saw the new oslo.limit patches but didn't dig in deeper for review yet. It's on my TODO list.

I'm not sure I'm 100% following your example here but in general I agree that we only want to check limits related to the instance or action the user is trying to carry out.

I'm also realizing that multiple keystone calls can be made fast by doing them in parallel, so in that regard maybe a batch ability is not needed.

To be clear, what I was thinking originally was, one batch call to keystone for all limits for a project and then on the client side only selectively use the ones related to the request. But now, with the idea of parallel requests to keystone in mind for multiple limits, we could just have them be separate calls and do them in parallel, only for the limits related to the request at hand.

Hopefully what I said makes sense.

I have the oslo.limit stuff up for review now (its actually lots of calls to keystone right now):
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695310

So... I think this is a bad idea now actually... because you can have an over limit error that is unrelated to the instance or action you are checking about. For example, if you reduce ironic quotas, then all your VMs will stop being created till you delete your ironic instances. Now someone may want that behviour, but that is very different to the current system, where its about if any of the resources this instance is claiming are needed.
Note to self: one call to placement to get all usages.
Note to self: this will call keystone N deltas times sequentially and call placement once to get all usages in a batch.

nova/limits/local.py.message: I'm trying to figure out what we mean by delta. Do we mean the difference between available limits and current usage? Or do we mean the resources the user is trying to claim?

Yeah, I think so.

We probably call usage counts now.

Historically we used to store the claims/reservations in the DB, and we moved to counting.

Got it, that makes sense. I liked the terminology sdague used when we first start working on this.

limit == an integer representing the upper bound of a resource you can consume
usage == the number of resources you currently have
claim == the number of resources you're trying to obtain in a request

In the historical implementation, it sounds like:

limit == quota
usage == quota (in a way because quotas handled both, right?)
claim == delta

?

good point, its a historic name. It means "additional" usage we want to check.

Historically we used to do negatives in certain cases (resize down). Probably needs a better name, like additional_usage.

This is a bit confusing when considered alongside COUNTABLE_ENTITIES. I understand COUNTABLE_ENTITIES to be things that we can count locally in our database.

COUNT_LIMITS are not the same though (no counting of database items). But they're named so similarly. That said, I can't think of a better name at the moment. Just something to think about.

The more I think about the original names "count limits" vs "countable entities" the more they make sense to me. So now I'm not feeling confident about different naming being needed.

But, I think API_REQUEST_LIMITS might be closer. I was trying to work out what these limits actually are. They are limits where if the user asks for more than N of these things, we reject them. And it seems like API_REQUEST_LIMITS would capture that meaning a bit better.

Good point... I did try to add API into there, to make it clear its related to the API request.

Maybe API_REQUEST_LIMITS might be better.
FWIW I don't think this one is confusing as-is, it was COUNT_LIMITS that threw me. I'm neutral about changing it.
This is what I meant about not needing the if/else everywhere.
Oh, thanks for pointing this out. I missed the connection for some reason.
I must admit I like the proposed new names for the limit check methods because of the symmetry and making it a bit more obvious what's happening.

nova/scheduler/client/report.py.message: Need to make the fact this is no longer the case much clearer.

As stephenfin noted in a review comment earlier on, this will be a change in behavior from the current quota system. Currently, "cores" quota adds VCPU + PCPU when considering usage, see L2515.

If anyone thinks this would be a problem, please add a comment.
Yeah, I think I'd rather the reno say "you might want to turn on this workaround if upgrading" instead of "you might want to do math, and then do different math again later".

Hmm, that sounds like a problem for anyone that runs hot. I guess we really can't fix it for the old method, but maybe we should add a workaround flag to opt into summing them for keystone-based quotas until they can sort their usage? I guess we could also tell people to halve that quota when they create it in keystone, but for some reason that seems like it might be worse as it could change the dynamics a lot if there are some users on a system that don't use any PCPUs.

Workaround flag sounds like a nice way to handle this. Adding VCPU + PCPU by default would feel odd in the new scheme considering that placement tracks VCPU and PCPU separately, you can set quotas class:VCPU and class:PCPU separately, and you can also make flavors with separate resources:VCPU and resources:PCPU. So having to opt-in via [workarounds] makes sense.

Yeah, halving quota would also be an option. As you point out, the reno would have to say something like, "if you use PCPU in your deployment, you will want to halve your class:VCPU and class:PCPU quota limits".

I've added the workarounds option and added it to the reno at the end of this set.

Note that I have initially not merged VCPU + PCPU if PCPU has been explicitly specified in the flavor. My thinking is that if it's in the flavor as "PCPU" then it is the expectation of the operator for it to have its own limit registered and usage be counted separately despite the config option being set to True.

This ^ might be me lacking understanding of how PCPU is used, though. If it is/was expected to be present in the flavor but only the quota limit for VCPU be used, then I need to merge it no matter what when the workaround is True. Let me know if I should change it.
Here is where VCPU + PCPU happens.
