In your tests, it looks like we're now raising QuotaError for being over quota - is that right?

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/712139/27/nova/tests/unit/limit/test_local.py#127

I hadn't thought much about it when seeing that (being over quota is a sort of quota error). However, here it looks like we had been expecting an OverQuota here and in our caller. It surely seems like we should differentiate from the "session init error" and the "everything is fine, you're just out of quota" situation. Especially since our caller expects a more specific KeypairLimitExceeded exception in that case, as opposed to the more general "I dunno, something broke with quotas."
Done

> Your thought makes sense to me. What I ultimately am trying to do here is switch over to the oslo.limit "over quota" exception message and make the "over quota" exceptions consistent (in response to previous feedback not to jump through hoops to preserve the legacy inconsistent over quota exception messages).

Yep, I know that's what you're going for and I think it's good in general. If I hadn't said it earlier, I think standardizing services' responses about quota issues on what oslo-limit gives us is nice. It's straightforward, gives a lot of information to the user, etc.

> So far, I've done that by generically catching oslo_limit.exception.ProjectOverLimit, taking its <message> and raising a nova.exception.QuotaError with <message>. The nova.exception.OverQuota has an entirely different msg_fmt [1], so I can't reuse it AFAIK. And exceptions like KeypairLimitExceeded all have inconsistent exception messages.
> 
> (later) I see now that any nova exception message can be overridden using the 'message' kwarg, so the exception classes could in fact be reused with different user-facing words.

Ah, I see why you did that then. But yeah, I think it'd be better to continue using the same class if we can, but with the better message from oslo-limit. Granular exceptions help us do the right thing in the API, and not having two ways to expose an overquota situation above a given layer helps us not introduce bugs later. Someone looking at that stack of exceptions in the API clearly thinks if they're looking for the overquota situation that they should look for KeypairLimitExceeded, which would be wrong IFF we're using the keystone driver under the covers.

> Fair point about the "session init error", that it should be different than a "over quota" error. I'll change that somehow.

Cool.

> Some questions:
> 
> (1) Is translating oslo.limit exceptions to nova exceptions at the nova.limit layer the right thing to do in general? Or should nova.limit pass through oslo.limit exceptions and compute.api catches them and raises nova exceptions? Or should nova pass through oslo.limit exceptions all the way out the REST API? Or something else I've not thought of?

I would think that they should be translated at least in the compute.api layer, if not the nova.limit layer. Wherever the earliest opportunity for same behavior is, I think. If nova.limit can behave just like the config-based approach or whatever, then that's better if compute.api doesn't have to account for both possibilities.

> (2) If translating to nova exceptions in some way is the answer to (1), should they all be the same nova.quota.OverQuota or should they keep their existing nova exception classes and just override using the 'message' kwarg to use the consistent error message from oslo.limit?

I think we should preserve the Nova classes whenever it makes sense (i.e. there's a direct relation). Meaning QuotaError for actual error things (like the session init case) and KeypairLimitExceeded for "you are out of these". Since the new layer is more unified than the old one(s) it might help to introduce a layer of "too many things" exception parent class in front of KeypairLimitExceeded, TooManyServerGroups, WhyDoYouNeedSoManyMetadataItems, etc (made up those last two, but you get the idea) so that the api can generically catch OverQuotaForThing and your generic layer can raise the generic OverQuotaForThing instead of the specific KeypairLimitExceeded.

Your thought makes sense to me. What I ultimately am trying to do here is switch over to the oslo.limit "over quota" exception message and make the "over quota" exceptions consistent (in response to previous feedback not to jump through hoops to preserve the legacy inconsistent over quota exception messages).

So far, I've done that by generically catching oslo_limit.exception.ProjectOverLimit, taking its <message> and raising a nova.exception.QuotaError with <message>. The nova.exception.OverQuota has an entirely different msg_fmt [1], so I can't reuse it AFAIK. And exceptions like KeypairLimitExceeded all have inconsistent exception messages.

(later) I see now that any nova exception message can be overridden using the 'message' kwarg, so the exception classes could in fact be reused with different user-facing words.

Fair point about the "session init error", that it should be different than a "over quota" error. I'll change that somehow.

Some questions:

(1) Is translating oslo.limit exceptions to nova exceptions at the nova.limit layer the right thing to do in general? Or should nova.limit pass through oslo.limit exceptions and compute.api catches them and raises nova exceptions? Or should nova pass through oslo.limit exceptions all the way out the REST API? Or something else I've not thought of?

(2) If translating to nova exceptions in some way is the answer to (1), should they all be the same nova.quota.OverQuota or should they keep their existing nova exception classes and just override using the 'message' kwarg to use the consistent error message from oslo.limit?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9fe465427310f8215890d26bf169617653605e23/nova/exception.py#L996-L997
Cool, makes sense. I'll get this cleaned up, thank you for the help.

I think when you see stuff like this, especially repeated so many times, it's an indicator that we're doing something wrong. It took me a while to figure out what's going on here, but I think I see. When I suggested tweaking this last time, I mentioned an extra layer in here. Looking more closely at the actual exceptions, I think the easiest thing to do would be to add a subclass to OverQuota like "OverQuotaLimit" (or some better name) which we raise in our limit-based code, and which can catch specifically and use the message unchanged, instead of inspecting the way the message was formatted. But, I think there's an even better option:

We're already templating the methods that we call per quota key in these enforce methods. We could easily also template out the exception that we want raised. That way enforce_db_limit() could just raise KeypairLimitExceeded directly (in that case) and we wouldn't need this layer of translation at all. When we remove the nova-internal quotas then these bits can really just go away.

Some other options would also be to use the first option but just teach the KeypairLimitExceeded type exceptions to honor a limit-based subclass so we can avoid the conditional behavior here entirely.

Anyway, I think adding this if..else behavior everywhere is not very palatable, so we should work on a better way. I started the discussion so I'll definitely help get us out.
Done
no need for a microversion change here too.
Here the legacy exception message will not change because Quotas.limit_check() raises a generic OverQuota exception which is caught below.
don't we want to pass forward the better error message from the quota code?
Ack

We do in the case of L413, because that will have been generated by the new limit code and have the new-style error. This is the unchanged original code, which uses the standard error message in the exception.
don't we want to pass forward the message from the OverQuota?

Same as above, this is the legacy case, so we want the mesage from the exception, which is keypair-specific if we're not using the new limits stuff. This is why I moved that string into the KeypairLimitExceeded exception in the earlier patch. In the legacy case, we raise KeypairLimitExceeded with the static string that users have always seen, and in the new limit case (L6577) we raise the one that the limit code gave us, which has the new oslo.limit-style message in it.
Ack
I guess we need save_and_reraise_exception for this destroy for the same reason as it is added at L6657
I agree about not reraising the OverQuota if that has only a generic message. I wanted to point out the case when destroy() raises.

No, because we don't want to re-raise the generic OverQuota, we want to keep raising the KeypairLimitExceeded exception, as this code has always done. We might want to put a try..except around the destroy to make sure we don't fail to raise the exception we want, but we do not want to raise the generic OverQuota as it won't have the keypair-specific string in it that we want to keep in the legacy case.

I put save_and_reraise_exception() to reraise KeypairLimitExceeded after destroying the keypair. If destroy() itself raised, in both cases it would just go unhandled in both cases, unless I'm missing something.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
More on why this is a good thing: Just *attempting* the delete will clear both info and listing shard ranges from cache: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.28.0/swift/proxy/controllers/container.py#L552-L555

So in a big cluster, you could have hundreds of expirers all  trying to list and delete containers that are known to still be draining. If your expiry containers get large enough to shard (protip: if you get big enough, they will!), that means they're basically always going the slow way, querying shards from the root before building up a proper listing.

Meanwhile, the poor root's probably drowning trying to redirect updaters that want to clean up stale queue entries. Those guys *have* to get a redirect; the object server and the updater are the only ones that know the old queue time, and they don't have any handle to memcache.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
mechanically this looks great!  seems like a good idea - nice optimization

there was never any principled reason we cleaned up containers the way the existing code was written - i think it was mostly KISS, but there's a strong advantage to avoid cache busting calls when your expirer containers are big busy and sharded.

I couldn't quite follow the test churn.  It'd be nice to see something demonstrating the cache issue that fails when the change is reverted; but even some positive and negative (test_does_delete, test_does_not_delete) would be great.

Cool, so had a play with this today. Created a bunch of X-Delete-After objects, turned the expiring_objects_container_divisor down low so it'll use a bunch of expirer containers. 

Then ran the expirer one cycle at a time (from one node), and sure enough you see a bunch of objects expire, then next run their container is deleted. Not a bunch of container deletes all the time. So much more targetted.

I think this is a big win. nice one Tim!

Having to wait for another cycle to confirm the container is empty is fine. And because it's checking pre-skipping based on process/processes divisor maths we actually have great confidence it is empty. I love this!

I guess the only behavioural difference is the container deletes will be inlined with the expiry cycle (although a cycle later) rather then at the end, but I don't see that was a problem.

I'll +2 because it seems to be well tested and looks great. Haven't tested in my SAIO though so would like another +2 before merge (or wait for me to SAIO test on my Monday).

Time to go make dinner for the girls 😊

In my previous comment I wrote

  "There's a string argument for being less eager ..."

To avoid confusion, I meant to write:

  "There's a strong argument for being less eager ..."

The patch does not change any function arguments, string or otherwise 😊

Results from prod look great; went from hundreds of container 409s per second to, like, one. Listing-shard-range cache-miss percentage went from "usually in the 1-2% range with occasional spikes as high as 5%" to "under 0.5%, with only the occasional spike to 1-2%."
There's a string argument for being less eager to speculatively deleting containers, and the change is simple and expedient. LGTM but I haven't yet studied the unit tests in detail so only +1.

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
This is getting pretty deeply nested. It was deep before, but this is the point at which I'd be breaking out something, like the event loop, into a separate method so that this just looks like:

 try:
     with timeout:
         self.do_events()
     except timeout:
         ...

But just MHO.
Is there some reason to log events and not just event_names here? It will be a dict of name: Event() right? Seems like event_names would be easier to read.
You are right, a list of event_names is enough

I'm a little worried that this might mislead someone about what has happened here. I think that if you see this:

 events: vif-1, vif-2
 missing-event: vif-2

you are going to assume it's vif-2 that was the problem. However, if vif-1 took 299 seconds, you might go chasing vif-2 problems that aren't really there.

Maybe that doesn't make sense for the current situation, where we expect it's one vif that never gets the callback, but I wonder if it might be better to report the events we received and how long we waited for each, instead of just assuming the current one after the timeout was the problematic one?

Hm. My intention was that when nova times out there will be one log message that clearly states the reason as I'm lazy collecting the log messages "Instance event wait completed in %i seconds for" and the correlating that with the list of expected messages from "Preparing to wait for external event" log. 

As we did all the plugs in parallel if vif-1 take 299 seconds but vif-2 only takes 10 seconds then still after wait() returned with vif-1 the vif-2 will already been received and the next wait() call will return immediately without timing out. 

I think the more problematic case is when there are 3 events, second times out and therefore we never call wait() on the 3rd event so we don't know here if it is received or not. (We have a separate log about receiving events so from a wider log analysis this can be seen properly)

Anyhow I can combine the timing values into this LOG.warning message so at least the log reader has all pieces of available information in a single log.

Man, this is a lot of refactor to get the log message better :)

I _think_ it all looks right though...

nova/tests/unit/compute/test_virtapi.py.message: I wonder if this ends up just making this very long and hard to read. It's all duplicate information that is in the event_states dump right?

This might be perceived as a problem by someone looking at this now very long list of things and trying to figure out what the actual failure is. Like "does early mean TOO early?". It's maybe useful for debugging for us, but not really relevant to the analysis of a failure by an operator.

That said, I don't think it's worth changing on my account, I just wanted to point it out in case anyone else thinks it might be misleading.

I didn't think it would be OK to do something different underneath and not honor what the interface is showing. I thought it would be misleading. Reaching into the internals is ugly but it's not misleading. And I thought ugly would be preferable over misleading.

Well, personally I think reaching into the internals is not reasonable at all, because we'd break if the internals change. This is, IMHO, the extent of the public interface for oslo.limit:

https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.limit/latest/reference/api/oslo_limit.limit.html

> Re: (1) also, enforce will prefer a project limit if one exists and we aren't allowing that for these global default limits. There is no way to prevent enforce from "overriding" a registered limit with a project limit if one exists. We don't want any overrides here with global-only limits. With oslo.limit enforce, if an operator did create a project limit for say "server_metadata_items" that limit would take precedence over the default limit and if we used that project limit, it would be incorrect/misleading in that it implies enforcement scoped to a project when that is not actually what will happen.

I understand, but it's all based on the project_id you pass to it. Will keystone refuse to do the lookup if you use something that isn't a valid project_id? Either way, I think we need support in oslo.limit for this sort of thing by allowing for a None project_id to skip the project limit lookup. Just probing into the internals to skip half of the regular way it works is just asking for trouble, IMHO.

I think if you want to fetch the registered limit directly, it'd be better to use the client itself (i.e. what _get_registered_limit() does) instead of calling into oslo.limit internals. At least that's a stable library interface. Should be a fairly simple swap to that right?

> I agree that we need to add more interfaces to oslo.limit in order to do this better but oslo feature freeze was August 19, one day after we decided to change direction and put these "API and DB" limits into keystone. So I thought it was implied that we were not going to go for a perfect final version for the initial code landing.

Ack, TBH I didn't think this was likely to land in xena given how much above this hadn't seen much review until the last minute and things like this that I figured were waiting for actual interfaces.

OK, I may have missed the earlier discussed point about using a all-zeros project_id or similar until project_id=None is possible in oslo.limit. I will look into doing that.

And also that is a fair point about at least using the client connection itself instead of the private method; I didn't think of doing that.

Ack, I had thought it had a fair chance of landing in xena because most of the set had +2s and some +Ws on it prior to the decision to use unified limits for all limits.
I have changed everything over to using oslo.limit public interfaces using the empty/dummy project_id approach. It seems to have turned out nicely.
Done

I did this to get only a registered limit because (1) these limits cannot be project limits because they are not enforced per project, they are global only and (2) these resources are not things that fit the enforce counting model to count per project.

I didn't think it would be better to put them into enforce when they will not actually be counted scoped to a project (the enforce callback shows that they will be counted with a project scope). I didn't think it would be OK to do something different underneath and not honor what the interface is showing. I thought it would be misleading. Reaching into the internals is ugly but it's not misleading. And I thought ugly would be preferable over misleading.

Re: (1) also, enforce will prefer a project limit if one exists and we aren't allowing that for these global default limits. There is no way to prevent enforce from "overriding" a registered limit with a project limit if one exists. We don't want any overrides here with global-only limits. With oslo.limit enforce, if an operator did create a project limit for say "server_metadata_items" that limit would take precedence over the default limit and if we used that project limit, it would be incorrect/misleading in that it implies enforcement scoped to a project when that is not actually what will happen.

I agree that we need to add more interfaces to oslo.limit in order to do this better but oslo feature freeze was August 19, one day after we decided to change direction and put these "API and DB" limits into keystone. So I thought it was implied that we were not going to go for a perfect final version for the initial code landing.

I need to go further up the stack to see how this is used I guess, but the enforcer is optimized for checking multiple things in a single go, so it seems weird to wrap it in a single-shot interface. swift/obj/diskfile.py.message: How's this going to interact with sharded containers?
The directory is now the hash of the container or container-shard. By segmenting more, we can be more efficient in handling container-server troubles

swift/obj/updater.py.message:
I'm a little bit worried about the timing on this listdir -- previously we had updates splayed out by suffix, but now all updates for a container will be in the same directory... given that we're worried about a single container being overloaded or offline, leading to a pile-up of pendings... I'm concerned about the prospect of having hundreds of thousands or even millions of updates slow the ls.

Depending on what you configured, it could even get to be enough to dominate the time limit :-/

Maybe the path should be more like <c-hash>/<o-suffix>/<o-hash>-<o-timestamp>?
Right. The new patch create subdirectories under the container-directory, and it also avoid counting listdir and rate-limitation for the time spent on a container-directory.

We should find a way to still do this even when the time limit's up. Worst case with this patch, we've gone from

 obj1-t3    processed
 obj1-t2    deleted
 obj1-t1    deleted
 obj2-t4    processed

to

 obj1-t3    processed
            (time limit exceeded)
 obj1-t2    processed, but out of date
            (time limit exceeded)
 obj1-t1    processed, but out of date
            (time limit exceeded)
 obj2-t4    processed
Worth adding a stat for these, too?

Should be a good idea to delete container ohash folder if all update_path was unlinked. That was not a problem previously with ohash suffix (max 4096 folders). But with container that should grow a lot.
ap_iter should by renamed, it's not async pending dict anymore

The endpoint for the schedule reprocessing API will be:
 - `POST` `/v2/task/reprocess`

I'm not sure returning an empty dict is the best idea here. I feel empty objects indicate that nothing's been done and so we should at least add a brief message. But then, since we return the HTTP code, this might not matter that much.

Would you like to see something different?

Normally, in a post message, such as this one, I see the HTTTP 200 as enough. It is an API called schedule, where we send the data to schedule. just returning 200 would be enough. 

Would you like to see something else?
It's a bit unusual but let's go with it for now.

It's just that in my opinion returning an empty object instead of even a stock message like "reprocessing task scheduled successfully", may puzzle the user sending requests to the API (until the read the specs of course). On the other side, end users will, most likely, work with these APIs through a CLI which can then display status messages based on HTTP codes so the payload might just not matter.
Pierre: What do you think and what's normal practice in cases like this?
No need for extra line break?
The scope IDs to reprocess. Must be comma-separated to schedule more than one.

deployment/keystone/keystone-container-p.message: this doesn't look idempotent. Was the expectation to purge all certs for each deployment command run?
failure seems like the best scenario to me. and when we fail, the message should include how to proceed (manual cleanup).

Well, that really depends how it's configured ... is it only an empty DB that was created or was a TLS certificate manually configured in opendlap.conf ?

IE:

TLSCACertificateFile /etc/openldap/certs/ldapserver-cacerts.pem
TLSCertificateFile /etc/openldap/certs/ldapserver-cert.pem
TLSCertificateKeyFile /etc/openldap/certs/ldapserver-key.pem

or just /etc/openldap/certs/*.db ... which case should we validate ?  Both ?  Only the latter ?

We had an issue that took a few hours/days to fix during a FFU because there was a database in /etc/openldab/certs that was created by the operator or something like that.   It did override the /etc/pki/tls/ certs and broke openldap certificate validations ...  we can run it once, or every time we do an overcloud operation just to make sure someone didn't add it .   It would fall in the same scope as the libvirtd process being started and conflicting with ironic dnsmasq process, there shouldn't be certificates in that folder .   So we can move it elsewhere, leave it here or abandon this patch if you want.  I've seen this issue so far only once but it did take us a bit of time to figure out what was happening and this would've avoided that situation.

So the operator broke their environment, and this task is meant to prevent that in the future. That's important context, and explains why we would just delete a directory on every deployment.

I also think it's likely that in the case where the operator intentionally configured something, and then we go out of our way to delete it, could be very bad user experience. Even in this case, could we delete critical secret data (cert db)? Even if it's the right technical fix so we can proceed, that doesn't sound like good UX.

This feels more like a validation, or perhaps we fail if there are files in this directory instead of deleting them.
We could check if the cert database is empty, and delete it only in that case.

Well if we just fail, it'll still be a problem because the operator will be stuck there because of the certificates that shouldn't be there in a first place and if they put certificates there it should be done through tht and not any other ways ... imo.   I feel better with the deletion than the failure here tbh.
well, it's certainly idempotent. It's going to rm /etc/openldap/certs/* every time. but I definitely agree that the intent seems wrong. why would we need to delete these files every time?

deployment/logging/rsyslog-container-pup.message: Any reason this has to be role specific? Role specific parameters with an empty default are kind of an antipattern to the whole role_specific parameter implementation.

> Any reason this has to be role specific?
I'm adding this parameter to allow adding arbitrarily log files. Because we usually deploy different services in different roles, we are likely to have different set of log files in different roles. That's why I've made this role-specific.


> it seems that other *LoggingSource are not role specific
The other LoggingSource parameters defines log files generated by the services defined in that template file. Generally log files should be 'static' according to the services, so the other parameters don't need to be role-specific.
good question, it seems that other *LoggingSource are not role specific

nova/api/openstack/compute/volumes.py.message: Is this API called by cinder? If so will this work by default after we scoped it to project? I mean will the cinder call have the proper project_id?
Thanks. The plans with the service role sounds good as a long term solution

You are right on cinder's project_id. I re-checked the way cinder call the swap volume while migrating volume to a specific host (even neutron case for server external event). And yes cinder will not have the right project_id and we cannot check that project_id in nova policy enforcement against instance.project_id. 

Cinder uses the configured nova user for nova API call and project there can be different from server's project for which volume swap is called. In gate, cinder use the devstack created 'nova' user which has 'service' and 'admin' roles assigned in the project called 'service'. This is a good example of cinder using different projects used to interact with nova than where the server belongs to.

At the end for service-to-service interaction (discussing in service role spec[1]), below can be the workflow (but will be finalized once keystone spec is merged and we start discussion in phase-2):

- policy default is updated including the service role. Example:        
    "os_compute_api:os-volumes-attachments:swap='role:admin or role:service'"
    scope_type= ['project'] 
- operator cerate a project scoped user in keystone with role as 'service' in 'service' project.
- operator configure that service user to cinder (or neutron) in nova auth section in conder.conf.
- Cinder will use that service user to call nova's volume swap API and policy will pass as user is 'service' role and project scoped. 

But we need to wait for phase-2 to implement those in projects. Meanwhile, to keep the current behaviour, I will modify this policy default and remove the instance.project_id from policy target. 

Thanks a lot for catching this.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone-specs/+/818616/1/specs/keystone/yoga/default-service-role.rst#72

nova/policies/volumes_attachments.py.message: Either I misunderstood this or something is broken. In my understanding people having PROJECT_ADMIN creds are not supersets of people having PROJECT_MEMBER creds.

How I understood the above sentence:
We expect that a token that is accepted for "update" is also accepted for "swap". 

But a project member token that is accepted for "update" will not be accepted for "swap" as that need at least an project admin token
sure, I will update it along with adding context of it as note in followup patch.

It is a little tricky. In 2.86, this API is extended to update the volume also (previously it was only swap volume) and for that, we made the two separate policies for swap and update. And swap + update can be called together in >2.85. so we have the below cases: 

1. only update: update policy is checked. All good.
2. only swap: swap policy is checked. All good.
3. swap + update (>2.85): only swap policy is checked. This is the tricky part. 

   Case1:
    - update policy is member role
    - swap policy is admin role (this is a superset of update policy)
      - this means any user having a member role can do the update. If as an admin user I call swap+update then it satisfies the swap policy and so does allow me to do the update. Which does not violate the update policy permission(admin is allowed for member-allowed policy).

   Case2:
    - update policy is member role
    - swap policy is overridden to reader role by operator (this is not superset of update policy)
      - As a reader user I will call swap+update and as we check only swap policy it passes and allow me to update the attachment. Here the reader role, I am able to update the volume attachment which violates the update policy permission (which is member role). And to avoid this case,  we mentioned keep swap policy as a superset of the update policy always.

Hope I explained it to understand it than making more confusing :)

I think we should stop using superset terminology here. It is misleading.

When you say that the admin role is superset of the member role then it can be understood two ways:

a) the people having the admin role can do a set of actions X while people having the member role can do a set of actions Y. And X is a superset of Y.

b) the set of people having the admin role is the superset of the people having the member role. 

Based on your explanation the meaning a) is the one that is used in the text. But I was looked at this from the perspective of b) when I read this.

I suggest to change the text to:
We expect <swap policy> to be always at least as restrictive as the <update policy>

PROJECT_ADMIN is always superset of PROJECT_MEMBER. As per keystone implied roles, admin has role of ['admin', 'member', 'reader'] and member role as ['member', 'reader'].

Hope I understood your question correctly?
OK, I understand why you use this ADMIN role and not like https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/828670/4/nova/policies/quota_sets.py#55

Well, the right thing to do is to not raise the exception for a case that seems (to me) to be unexceptional. What was that field set to before we introduced the new value for the enum? We should set it to *that* during the backport (or potentially unset it) and not raise. The raise just breaks the upgrade potential exactly like you're seeing here. The point of obj_make_compatible() is not to notice and break incompatibilities, it's to ... make it compatible (when possible of course ;)

However, that job looks to me to be running on an x64 machine. Unless we're dealing with a host (or is it guest in this case?) with arch=riscv32, I'm not sure why we're failing here. Since there's no job change in that patch, I would guess that this is actually introducing some upgrade incompatibility that is causing us to trigger the raise in the backport, right?
Right, but the thing that is raising is saying that an object *has* that new enum set. Not that they're not available in v2, but that it's actually set to that. Why would that be in this case?

Sorry Pini, what I really think is the solution proposed here is in the wrong direction. A test case should fail only when there is a problem, and it should not fail only because it has been run twice. This change is increasing the complexity of workflows to workaround a flaw of a single test case of test case class that should be improved in python code. The behavior I would expect from this test case is the same as other scenario test cases:

1) first time it is executed it should start the process and verify that ping returns some successful results
2) other times the test is executed it should simply report it has been successful since the last time it has been executed
3) eventually we have to introduce a method to clean and ignore temporary failures just after some fault test case we expect could produce downtimes (like compute nodes reboots). Or alternatively such test cases should evacuate all VMs using live migration before rebooting compute nodes.

Anyway this type of test cases (background) should be flagged with @pytest.mark.background marker so that we can skip them in some jobs/steps.

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message: We need to use log instead of self.log to have annotated logging.
duration is a float. Since we're already in ms resolution we should cast it to int to avoid cluttering the log with too precise float formatting.

With disabled statsd reporting self.sched.statsd is None so we need to guard for that. Further stats reporting should not lead to failed reports so we need to catch exceptions there separately, see also https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/connection/__init__.py#L51
We still need to catch and log exceptions here since this stats reporting errors must not mark the report as failed.
Is this really necessary?  Doesn't seem to have much useful context and will be in the logs a lot?
ok, i guess if it's a result of debugging some real thing then it's useful enough

Yes, we wanted to have both, logs and stats. Since it is "debug" it can be turned off. The logging here enables us to detect if a concrete problem with an event was due to a reporter and which one. The stats do not contain such information. Is it a blocker for you?
This also -- we're logging it in the stat

To alleviate ianw's concern with logging maybe we can drop this log.info then in sendReport() record what is logged here. Then add in a second logger at debug log level that records the time taken? That way this line and "log.debug("Reporting to %s started", reporter.name)" aren't redundant?

Something like:

  log.info("Reporting item %s, actions: %s, to %s", item, actions, reporter.name)
  # Run reporter actions
  log.debug("Reporting %s to %s finished in %sms", item, reporter.name, duration_ms)

In sendReport()?
Yes, we needed to also see the start. This log could be IMHO removed or downgraded to debug.

I think we can drop the started log. If it blocks indefinitely zuul is blocked completely and a thread dump can reveal where it's blocked anyway (which is easier than spotting the last started message in a giant log).

I guess the issue is if it never came back, you didn't see that it even started (i.e. the database just ate requests or something?)  I guess it depends what inspired this.

But I support less debug messages, if appropriate.

cinderclient/v3/shell.py.message: and this parameter still have some argument, so we need change it after spec approved.

This is 'ignore-reserved' in the spec, so don't forget to go back and update the spec.  (I think it makes sense to have the same structure in the client as in the API, so I think you took the correct approach here.)

-1: We don't want "regular" users to re-image reserved volumes, so let's not make it easy for them.  Also, there's an ambiguity about what "Default=False" means.  What I mean is, the current help output is:

  usage: cinder reimage [--reimage-reserved [<True|False>]] <volume> <image-id>

  Rebuilds a volume with specified new image

  Positional Arguments:
    <volume>              Name or ID of volume to reimage
    <image-id>            The new image id.

  Optional Arguments:
    --reimage-reserved [<True|False>]
                          Enables or disables reimage for a volume that is in
                          reserved state otherwise only volumes in "available"
                          status may be re-imaged. Default=False.

So you can make this call:

  cinder reimage --reimage-reserved cd42b779-2e10-4... f51f4929-1ef9-4...

This is the same as "--reimage-reserved True"; the default=False only applies if you don't include the option at all.  So I think the help text is not clear about what happens if you leave the optional True|False out.

My suggestion is to remove the nargs and const parameters and thereby require the user to explicitly specify either True or False when the --reimage-reserved option is used.

now it fails if we don't pass True/False value

| 81fd4884-772f-4c05-8e67-2444d263e707 | reserved  | boot_vol | 1    | True           | ceph        | true     |             |

stack@devstack-VirtualBox:~/python-cinderclient$ cinder reimage --reimage-reserved 81fd4884-772f-4c05-8e67-2444d263e707 e71ca3fb-ed97-47d5-b61f-29dec0f07d8e
usage: cinder reimage [--reimage-reserved <True|False>] <volume> <image-id>
error: the following arguments are required: <image-id>
Try 'cinder help reimage' for more information.

Also fails if --reimage-reserved is False (at API layer)

stack@devstack-VirtualBox:~/python-cinderclient$ cinder reimage --reimage-reserved False 81fd4884-772f-4c05-8e67-2444d263e707 e71ca3fb-ed97-47d5-b61f-29dec0f07d8e
ERROR: Invalid volume: Volume 81fd4884-772f-4c05-8e67-2444d263e707 status must be available or error, but current status is reserved. (HTTP 400) (Request-ID: req-d48534f3-d6bf-4a38-ace6-eca56cd01871)

Works if --reimage-reserved is True

stack@devstack-VirtualBox:~/python-cinderclient$ cinder reimage --reimage-reserved True 81fd4884-772f-4c05-8e67-2444d263e707 e71ca3fb-ed97-47d5-b61f-29dec0f07d8e

DEBUG cinder.volume.manager [req-308b3e7b-75c5-49e5-ae32-142dcd410698 req-8dac91ec-9ac9-4758-8347-6bc8b500440a admin None] Re-image e71ca3fb-ed97-47d5-b61f-29dec0f07d8e to volume 81fd4884-772f-4c05-8e67-2444d263e707 successfully. {{(pid=10342) reimage /opt/stack/cinder/cinder/volume/manager.py:5324}}

The --reimage-reserved is eating the volume-id as its parameter, so that's why the message is slightly misleading ("error: the following arguments are required: <image-id>").  But you also have the "usage" sentence that clearly shows that you need True or False as an argument, so I don't think we need to worry about it.

Also, the current code will allow you to make a call like this:

  cinder reimage --reimage-reserved Whatever volume1 image1

The call will be made to cinder and will be rejected by the schema validation, so I think we don't need to harden this now.

How about:

  help='The image id of the image that will be used to reimage the volume."

How about:

  Rebuilds a volume, overwriting all content with the specified image

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Looks like Chris got to this first! In case it ever comes up in the future, the dependency chain is Sphinx requires Jinja2, which in turn requires MarkupSafe>=2.0, and a recent version of MarkupSafe that came out (2.1.0) remove a function that Jinja2 uses. Therefore, the fix is to pin MarkupSafe to 2.0.1 which satisfies the >=2.0 requirement while still having the function Jinja2 needs. It is likely that Jinja2 will update soon to use the latest MarkupSafe version, so if there are other changes that are not compatible with version 2.0.1, the tox gate may fail again in the future. The fix is to either pin the Jinja2 version now, or in the future, if and when 2.0.1 no longer works with the newest Jinja2, remove the MarkupSafe pinned version that this patch implements. Posting this for reference and posterity, in case somebody from the future comes looking..

zuul/driver/zuul/__init__.py.message: Does it make sense to make this part of the ZuulTriggerEvent __init__ method then it will always have the value? Might make for a good followup to avoid this type of bug in the future.

zuul/scheduler.py.message: Actually, after looking at this a little bit more, let's not change the class hierarchy in this change.  I think pulling on that thread unravels more.

Is there a case where we forward `PipelinePostConfigEvents`? In the manager we are adding them directly to the pipeline management event queue.

I think the `_forward_management_event()` method will also fail for `PipelinePostConfigEvents` as it expects an event that has a tenant and pipeline name.
No, but this just seemed more correct and descriptive.  We should probably add tenant+pipeline as required attributes of PipelineManagementEvents to make this more robust.

I originally figured the risk was small and mitigated by the high probability another event would come along.  The alternative is to "peek" at the pipeline state (we already do that elsewhere to read the layout uuid), but I didn't want to keep doing that, especially inside a loop where we would likely immediately read the state again after peeking.  That's why I went with the event: to keep the number of things to check to a minimum.

But combined with the point below, perhaps we should address this situation generically.  We could write a flag znode indicating it's "dirty" when we start processing the pipeline, and then clear it below where we set STATE_NORMAL.  We'll add a check for the flag to the list of conditions where we process a pipeline.  If we hit either of these two situations, the flag will remain, and another scheduler can process it.

If the scheduler fails here or crashes it processed all the events but may not have processed the queue. So in those rare cases the pipeline may be stuck until there is an event for it. Do we want to cover this case or should we accept this risk?
I just wanted to make sure that we thought about this case. I think the dirty flag is a good idea for an enhancement in a followup.
As noted on Matrix following up to make the dirty flag change is a good thing, but we can get away with this for now so approving as is.
We may want to enqueue a PipelinePostConfigEvent here so the pipeline gets retried in the next loop.

I'm working on this now, making these declarative instead of just math. I'm hoping a compromise between the two will suffice. Instead of something like this:

 self.existing_set - set([one, two])

I'm going to do:

 self.existing_set = self.all_project_contexts - set([one, two])

Basically, not giving up on the set math because it makes it much easier to reason, but at least not depending on what is set in the parent so it's easier to look at a single line and determine the full ... set.

Also, I'm going to make those changes with a helper, which will log the difference from the parent's version *and* ensure that no subclass is *expanding* permission, which I think we should always be able to assert.
